channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Fisher-Price recalls 2 million Snuga Swings after infant deaths
item.description: The deaths of five infants ages 1-3 months old occurred from 2012 to 2022. It's not the first time the New York-based company has had to remove products from the market following infant fatalities.
item.content:encoded: The deaths of five infants ages 1-3 months old occurred from 2012 to 2022. It's not the first time the New York-based company has had to remove products from the market following infant fatalities.
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: There’s been 38 eyewitness-reported tornados in Florida: Why did Milton cause so many?
item.description: “We ended up with 126 tornado warnings” in Florida, Matthew Elliott, the warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service’s Storm Prediction Center, told NPR.
item.content:encoded:
“We ended up with 126 tornado warnings” in Florida, Matthew Elliott, the warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service’s Storm Prediction Center, told NPR.

(Image credit: Saul Martinez/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Floridians survey Milton's damage and get ready for a lengthy recovery
item.description: More than 3 million Floridians were without power after Milton. In some areas like Siesta Key, damage was severe. In Sarasota, many residents were thankful things were not worse.
item.content:encoded:
More than 3 million Floridians were without power after Milton. In some areas like Siesta Key, damage was severe. In Sarasota, many residents were thankful things were not worse.

(Image credit: Sergio Martínez-Beltrán)
item.dc:creator: Sergio Martínez-Beltrán

item.title: What a Hospital in War-torn Sudan Looks Like
item.description: Sudan's war has displaced more than 10 million people and half the country faces starvations. The country's medical services have collapsed leaving a patchwork of charities, local groups and the Sudanese diaspora to try to provide what health care they can. NPR's Africa correspondent takes us to one of the few remaining hospitals, near the Sudanese capital.
item.content:encoded: Sudan's war has displaced more than 10 million people and half the country faces starvations. The country's medical services have collapsed leaving a patchwork of charities, local groups and the Sudanese diaspora to try to provide what health care they can. NPR's Africa correspondent takes us to one of the few remaining hospitals, near the Sudanese capital.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: Are you in the process of buying or selling a home? We want to hear from you.
item.description: The housing market these days isn't easy. We want to hear from you about what it's like to buy or sell a home right now.
item.content:encoded: The housing market these days isn't easy. We want to hear from you about what it's like to buy or sell a home right now.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley

item.title: Diwali Barbie has arrived! What Indians are saying about the doll's skin tone and vibe
item.description: The new doll is being scrutinized for the color of her skin, her facial features and her garb. Early reviews are Barbie-tastic.
item.content:encoded:
'/>

The new doll is being scrutinized for the color of her skin, her facial features and her garb. Early reviews are Barbie-tastic.

(Image credit: Rafael Ortega / Mattel Inc.)
item.dc:creator: Kamala Thiagarajan

item.title: Rare comet to streak across night sky. Here’s how you can see it
item.description: Your unusual chance to see a comet in the sky is here. C/2023 A3 Tsuchinshan-ATLAS was discovered by astronomers in 2023 — and will appear to the naked eye over the next couple weeks.
item.content:encoded:
Your unusual chance to see a comet in the sky is here. C/2023 A3 Tsuchinshan-ATLAS was discovered by astronomers in 2023 — and will appear to the naked eye over the next couple weeks.

(Image credit: Mariana Suarez)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: 'That’s a bloodbath': How a federal program kills wildlife for private interests
item.description: A federal program kills hundreds of thousands of wild animals a year. Documents obtained by NPR show that many of those animals were killed in places where no damage to livestock was reported.
item.content:encoded:
A federal program kills hundreds of thousands of wild animals a year. Documents obtained by NPR show that many of those animals were killed in places where no damage to livestock was reported.

(Image credit: Obtained from the USDA via FOIA)
item.dc:creator: Chiara Eisner

item.title: Internationally acclaimed Israeli writer Etgar Keret looks back on a year of war
item.description: Keret, who lives in Tel Aviv, reflects on the protests in Israel and the U.S. over the hostages and Gaza. The son of Holocaust survivors, he has left- and right-wing political views in his own family.
item.content:encoded: Keret, who lives in Tel Aviv, reflects on the protests in Israel and the U.S. over the hostages and Gaza. The son of Holocaust survivors, he has left- and right-wing political views in his own family.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Why does it feel so weird to ride in a driverless car?
item.description: Driverless cars are expanding into more markets across the country. In San Francisco they’re already ubiquitous, but the robo-taxis' behaviors are unsettling riders.
item.content:encoded:
Driverless cars are expanding into more markets across the country. In San Francisco they’re already ubiquitous, but the robo-taxis' behaviors are unsettling riders.

(Image credit: Chloe Veltman)
item.dc:creator: Chloe Veltman
